Research Paper Noncovalent bond-aided MCN catalysis towards carbon dioxide by metal-doped graphitic carbon nitride Hong-Bo Zhao Writing – original draft Investigation a Hong-Xue Cai Formal analysis Data curation b Qing-Jiang Pan Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization b ⁎ a Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Suihua University, Suihua 152061, China Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Engineering Suihua University Suihua 152061 China aDepartment of Food and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Suihua University, Suihua 152061, China b Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Ministry of Education), School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Ministry of Education) School of Chemistry and Materials Science Heilongjiang University Harbin 150080 China bKey Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Ministry of Education), School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, China ⁎ Corresponding author. With raising carbon neutrality needs, it is crucial to develop efficient catalytic materials that effectively convert atmospheric CO2 to value-added chemicals. The well-studied MNx C single-atom catalysts usually experienced a single-center CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). In the work, the MCN catalysts have been designed by doping Sc/Y/La/Ac into graphitic carbon nitride, in anticipation of fabricating multi-center synergistic catalysis from not only the metal center but adjacent non-metal ligand atoms as well. The CO2RR has been systematically explored using relativistic density functional theory calculations in combination with molecular dynamics simulations. All these catalysts activated CO2 by bending its rigid linear structure. The CO2→M dative bond appears only in the adduct of Sc. Unexpectedly, additional two non-covalent tetrel bonds were recognized in the CO2 adducts of Y, La and Ac. Three catalytic active sites (MCN) are rendered by catalysts, which form a planar five-membered ring with CO of CO2. From a thermodynamic perspective, the YCN complex suggests the best catalytic potential. It has the most negative (-0.247 eV) and moderate (0.662 eV) free energy changes for CO2 adsorption and CO desorption, respectively. Further analyses on geometric/electronic structures and chemical bonding confirm the excellent stability and electronic transfer capability of MCN catalyst in activating CO2. Graphical abstract The doping of Sc, Y, La and Ac into graphitic carbon nitride enables to catalyze thermodynamically stable and kinetically inert CO2. Density functional theory and molecular dynamics calculations suggest a good catalytic activity for the YCN catalyst. It exploits three catalytic active sites (metal and adjacent ligand atoms) to start CO2RR. Barring the O→Y dative bond, additional two noncovalent tetrel bonds help to the multiple cooperative catalysis. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-doped g–C3N4 M–C–N cooperative catalysis CO2RR Noncovalent tetrel bonds DFT and molecular dynamics calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) offers a sustainable approach to convert CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuels, contributing to carbon neutrality and renewable energy applications [1–4]. Recent advancements have demonstrated CO2RR’s potential for producing CO, formic acid, methanol, and other hydrocarbon fuels [5–7], which are essential for industrial and energy sectors. Designing efficient catalysts to activate carbon dioxide (CO2) and convert it into valuable chemicals and clean fuels has shown considerable promise [8,9]. However, due to the profound thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness of CO2, its efficient conversion requires catalysts having high activation capabilities [10–12]. Therefore, the development of efficient and durable catalysts has become an ever demanding. Regarding this, the high efficiency and unique electronic structures of single atom catalysis (SACs) [13–18], which confer excellent catalytic activity and selectivity, have gathered significant attention in recent years. The core advantage of SACs lies in their ability to fully exploit the potential of metal atoms by providing isolated active sites, while simultaneously reducing the usage of precious metals. Thus, it enhances the economic and environmental sustainability of the catalysts. Among non-platinum group metal catalysts, rare-earth metals, particularly ones of the scandium group, have demonstrated substantial application potential owing to their distinct electronic configurations and superior catalytic properties. Moreover, recent reports prove that doping nitrogen-containing substrates with rare earths significantly has enhanced the catalytic activity towards oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and other electrocatalytic processes [19–25]. For instance, Sc-doped carbon nitride materials showed excellent ORR performance in both 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 solutions, with onset and half-wave potentials comparable to or even surpassing platinum-based catalysts [19]. Furthermore, Y supported by nitrogen-doped carbon materials have also displayed remarkable catalytic efficiencies [20–22]. In addition to these, previous studies on catalysts coordinated with silylamido ligands, such as [Mm(LMe)3]n and [MmL3]n (M = Sc, Y, La, Ac; LMe = {N(SiMe3)2}–; L = {N(SiH3)2}–; m = III, II; n = 0, −1), have highlighted the potential of scandium group metal complexes in CO2 activation [23]. These findings provide a solid foundation for the development of new, efficient group 3 metal catalysts. Porous material systems have also been considered as ideal supports for efficient catalysis due to their high dispersion, tunable pore structures, enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity, improved catalyst stability and ability to accelerate the diffusion of reactants. Ni-loaded porous N-doped carbon (NiNC) materials have demonstrated a Faradaic efficiency for CO as high as 92.1 % in CO2RR, along with remarkable stability [26]. Additionally, catalysts supported by porous porphyrin triazine frameworks have achieved the highest CO production rates at relatively mild potentials [27]. Despite these advancements, achieving precise control over synergistic effects between metal center at catalytic site and certain non-metallic atoms along with optimum CO2 adsorption and target products desorption balance remains significant challenging [28–31]. Graphitic carbon nitride (gC3N4) [32], a two-dimensional layered material, has emerged as an ideal support in metallic catalysis due to its excellent electrical conductivity, chemical stability, and tunable geometric/electronic structure [29,33,34]. By doping metals into g-C3N4, the nitrogen sites of gC3N4 can effectively stabilize metal atom, creating highly active sites that enhance the catalytic performance for CO2 reduction. As mentioned above [20], combining scandium group metals with nitrogen-doped carbon (ScNC) materials significantly improves both the activity and stability of catalysts in electrochemical reactions. Sc, Y, La, and Ac were selected for their unique electronic structures, oxidative stability, and high coordination potential. These elements all possess three valence electrons, exhibit similar chemical properties, and offer a valuable opportunity to explore electronic effects on CO2RR. Sc, Y, and La are rare earth elements, while Ac belongs to the actinide series. It may introduce subtle electronic discrepancy that would influence catalytic performance. Their single d-electron limits high-valence oxide formation, preventing oxidative degradation and enhancing durability. The large atomic radii and electron-rich orbitals enable stable high-coordination structures with nitrogen and carbon, improving single-atom catalyst (SAC) stability. Experimental studies confirm that Sc- and Y-based SACs exhibit catalytic activity for NRR and CO2RR [20,35], supporting their selection. Graphitic carbon nitride (gC3N4) serves as a suitable support, stabilizing SACs and enhancing small molecule activation through charge transfer and electronic modifications. These factors make Sc, Y, La, and Ac promising candidates for catalytic applications. More discussion on the choice of metal centers has been addressed in Supporting Information. In contrast to well-known MNC catalysts and recent studies on β12-borophene-supported single-atom catalysts (SACs) [36,37], which usually took a single-metal-center catalysis mechanism, we systematically investigated the MCN catalysts by doping Sc/Y/La/Ac into the cavity of gC3N4. Their CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) was studied by relativistic density functional theory (DFT) calculations and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The catalyst and its interaction with CO2 were addressed to explore the reaction pathways and elucidate the catalytic mechanism. It is found that the YCN catalyst is effective for CO2RR in terms of detailed structural, bonding, charge partitioning and thermodynamics analyses. In this work, we emphasized the unique role of tetrel bonds in CO2 activation, enabling a multi-center, synergistic interaction [38] that stabilizes the CO2 intermediate. Unlike systems based on dual active centers on gC3N4, which focused on C C coupling for C2 product formation [39], our multi-center MCN active sites created a novel mechanistic pathway where both metal atoms and non-metal ligands cooperate. This new design strategy offers enhanced CO2RR performance, particularly for selective CO generation. 2 Computational details A series of metal-doped catalysts were designed and constructed using a molecular unit of graphitic carbon nitride (denoted by CN). The selection of the gC3N4 structural model was described in Supporting information and Fig. S1. These catalysts were labeled as [M(CN)] (M = Sc, Y, La and Ac), where the metal atoms are embedded within the cavities of the graphitic carbon nitride. Notably, the complex was also mentioned using the labelling of the MCN catalyst, which addressed its three catalytic active sites towards CO2. Their schematic representation is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Considering the involvement of metals with three valence electrons in these catalysts, the electronic spin states (ESSs) of doublet and quartet isomers were considered. As shown in Table S1 of Supporting Information, the doublet state appears to be more stable. Therefore, all the species were modeled in the low-spin state. Geometric optimizations of all structures were first performed using the Priroda Version 6.0 program [40–42]. The calculations employed scalar relativistic Hamiltonian, all-electron Gaussian basis sets and PBE functional under the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [43–48]. No symmetry constraints were applied during the optimization process. The optimized geometries were validated via frequency calculations to confirm the absence of imaginary frequencies, indicating that all structures are located at minima on the potential energy surface. Thermodynamic data, electron spin densities, Mulliken charges, and Mayer bond orders at 298.15 K were also obtained. To gain deeper insights into bonding characteristics and electronic structures of catalysts and intermediates, single-point energy calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program [49]. The Stuttgart relativistic small-core effective core potentials (ECPs) and corresponding basis sets were applied to describe the central metal atoms, while the Pople’s 6–31G* basis sets were used for C, H, O and N atoms. Topological analysis of the chemical bonds at the bond critical points (BCPs) and electronic wavefunction analysis were performed using the MultiWFN software [50]. Quantum Theory of Atoms in Molecules (QTAIM) parameters, such as electron density ρ(r), Laplacian of electron density ∇²ρ(r), and energy density H(r), along with other chemical bonding information were obtained accordingly. The dispersion interaction was considered using Grimme’s D3 correction [51], implemented via the ADF code [52–55]. Finally, to assess the thermodynamic stability of the catalysts, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were conducted using the DFTB+ program [56]. The simulations were carried out under NVT ensemble using Nosé-Hoover chain thermostat to maintain the system temperatures at 298.15 K and 500 K. The GFN2-xTB Hamiltonian [57] was employed to describe the interaction of ions and electrons. A simulation time step of 1 fs and a total simulation time of 10 ps were taken. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures and stability of catalysts Due to the highest formal shortness ratio FSRM-N value of 1.079 and smallest MN bond order of 0.32 (Table 1 ), relatively weak bonding between ScN is found in [Sc(CN)]. The atomic radius and FSR definition are given in the footnote of the same table [58]. In contrast, [Y(CN)] exhibits lower FSRM-N (1.032) and larger bond order (0.35). This implies that YN bond is somewhat stronger than the ScN bond. However, FSR data and bond order suggest that La and Ac complexes have even stronger MN bonds than [M(CN)] (M = Sc and Y). An obvious trend could be observed in the deviation distances of M from the N6 plane. It consistently increases from Sc to Ac, corresponding to 0.042, 0.133, 0.614, and 0.864 Å. This trend is consistent with the increasing atomic radius of metal. In addition, the optimized NMN bond angles (α) further support this observation. When α approaches 60°, the metal resides within the plane. From these aspects, Y shows minimal deviation from the N6 plane. Notably, increasing MN bond strength would stabilize the catalyst system, while enlarging MN6 and contracting α could destabilize it. Taken together, [Y(CN)] has the highest structural stability among the four catalysts. This could be further elaborated by QTAIM analyses at MN BCP. As provided in Table 2 , the bond interaction energy Eint was computed to be −0.607 eV for YN, which is the most negative among the four. The YN bond has positive energy density H(r) and this along with ρ(r) > 0 and ∇2ρ(r) > 0 indicates typical ionic interaction [23,59,60]. The rest of [M(CN)] (M = Sc, La and Ac) have negative H(r) values that suggest dative bonds. Specifically, [Y(CN)] exhibit larger ρ(r) (0.0483) and ∇2ρ(r) (0.1815) than [Sc(CN)], indicating that the YN bond possesses more covalency and stronger bonding. The spin density and charge distribution find that [Y(CN)] exhibits negative spin density SY (−0.613) and a positive S CN value (1.613). It indicates significant α-spin electron transfer characteristics of the Y atom, which contribute to the enhanced stability of the catalyst. It is similar to [Ac(CN)]. In contrast, positive spin densities were calculated for [Sc(CN)] and [La(CN)], where the former has SM closer to the theoretically expected value of 1.0. This suggests that Sc atom has nearly one α single electron available for CO2 reduction. From the electronic-structure calculations[61], it could be noted that HOMO of [Y(CN)] is composed of 32.04 % Y and 67.96 % CN. Amongst these, the metal composition is mainly contributed by 18.68 % 4d and 13.39 % 5 s. The Sc complex exhibits more 3d composition (27.62 %) and less 4 s (10.18 %) in its HOMO. In comparison, [La(CN)] exhibits the lowest d orbital contribution (7.64 %), while [Ac(CN)] has negligible 5f contribution to HOMO. Further molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were conducted on [Y(CN)]. As shown in Fig. 2 , the total energy fluctuations at 298.15 and 500 K were minimal, indicating its high thermal stability at both temperatures. Thus, the high thermal and structural stability endows the catalyst with efficient CO2RR. Additionally, the main structural views obtained from MD calculations at 298.15 K are provided in the Fig. S2. These structures correspond to the snapshots taken at 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 ps. 3.2 CO2 reduction reactions Metal-doped graphitic carbon nitride catalysts, [M(CN)] (M = Sc, Y, La and Ac), were designed for the adsorption and activation of CO2. The catalytic reaction pathway (Scheme 1 ) illustrates the adsorption, activation, and stepwise reduction of CO2 to CO on these catalysts [62]. The structures of the corresponding intermediates have been depicted in Fig. 3 with comprehensive energy variation analysis during the CO2RR process. Depending on synergistic catalysis of metal centers and/or corresponding ligand, [M(CN)] (*) catalysts exhibit different capacities during the CO2 adsorption process. The Gibbs free energy changes (ΔrG) for CO2 adsorption on Sc, Y, La, and Ac catalysts are −0.214, −0.247, −0.214, and −0.135 eV, respectively (Fig. 4 ). In case of [Sc(CN)], the adsorption is more favored at the initial stage, giving −0.247 eV ΔrG, in contrast to −0.135 eV of [Ac(CN)]. The latter is the least negative value of the four catalysts, reflecting slight thermodynamic limitation. Subsequently, all the catalysts show a large negative free energy change during the formation of intermediates *(CO2H) and *(CO)(H2O), suggesting the thermodynamic preference and strong stability of these. In the step of releasing H2O molecule, La and Ac species require slightly more energy than the Y one. In the last step (CO desorption), all the catalysts experience an uphill process and this turns out to be the rate-limiting step in the entire CO2RR process. Specifically, the free energy changes for [Y(CN)] and [La(CN)] relative to respective preceding steps are moderate, corresponding to 0.662 and 0.613 eV. The value for [Sc(CN)] is relatively high (0.725 eV), suggesting this catalyst to be less favorable for CO desorption. Comparatively, the CO desorption is found the easiest for [Ac(CN)], which requires only 0.568 eV of energy. From a thermodynamic perspective, the [Y(CN)] catalyst exhibits the most negative free energy change during CO2 adsorption, while the CO desorption energy is moderate. This behavior is in strong agreement with the Sabatier principle. Consequently, yttrium emerges as a promising catalyst for CO2RR. [Y(CN)] was selected as the catalyst for CO2RR. Scheme 1 presents reaction pathways I and II, investigating the catalytic reduction products of CO, a 2e⁻ product, and formic acid (HCOOH). Initially, CO2 is captured by [Y(CN)] (denoted as *), where one oxygen atom binds yttrium and the carbon atom in CO2 couples with the N4 atom. During the initial adsorption step, CO2 undergoes activation due to the synergistic interaction between the metal active site and the adjacent non-metal ligand atom. The O CO linear structure of CO2 transforms into an angle of 141.5°, with bond lengths of 1.256 Å for O C and 1.185 Å for CO. As shown in Fig. 3, this activation continues in subsequent steps. Hydrogenation (H + + e –) leads to the formation of *CO2H and *COOH intermediates. As described in Scheme 1, the formation of *CO2H releases more energy than the formation of *COOH, promoting the generation of *(CO)(H2O) with a free energy release of 1.224 eV. This is followed by the removal of H2O and the generation of CO, overcoming energy barriers of 0.139 eV and 0.662 eV, respectively. Therefore, during the CO2RR process, the reaction follows the thermodynamically more favorable pathway I. Moreover, as shown in Fig. S3, we systematically explored multiple CO2 adsorption configurations, and the results confirm that the originally proposed [Y(CN)(CO2)] structure remains the most thermodynamically favorable for CO2 activation. To evaluate the HER competition, we calculated the (H + + e) adsorption Gibbs free energies (ΔGH*) at six possible active sites of the [Y(CN)] catalyst. All the results show unfavorable for HER, indicating effective suppression of this side reaction in our CO2RR (Fig. S4). 3.3 Systematic analyses of reaction intermediates Comprehensive analyses were conducted for all the possible intermediates during the CO2RR process. In Table 3 , we have provided the optimized geometry parameters for CO2 adducts, [M(CN)(CO2)] (M = Sc, Y, La and Ac). Interestingly, the CO2 moiety of Yttrium adduct has direct interaction with ligand atoms (Fig. 3). The corresponding C2···N4 and O1···C5 distances were calculated to be 2.011 and 2.680 Å. These are much shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (C···N of 3.22 Å and O···C of 3.12 Å), but longer than respective single bonds (1.46 and 1.38 Å) [58,63]. Interestingly, the four atoms along with the metal center construct a planar five-numbered ring. By measuring MC5N2C2O1, all the deviations of each atom from the plane are <0.0005 Å. The short M-O1 bond length of 2.214 Å was calculated in [Y(CN)(CO2)], having bond order of 0.55 and FSR of 0.980. It implies a strong interaction between the metal center and the oxo atom in CO2. Consequently, the O1C2-O3 bond angle turns bent (141.5°) from the linearity of the free CO2 (Fig. 3). At the same time, the O1C2 and C2-O3 bond lengths are elongated to 1.257 and 1.185 Å from 1.171 Å of the free molecule, respectively. Thermodynamically, the Yttrium adduct exhibits the most negative CO2 adsorption free energy (−0.247 eV). Similar general structures were acquired for [M(CN)(CO2)] (M = La and Ac), but it presented less activation on the CO2 moiety. The Sc adduct, however, gives a different appearance. The CO2 part interacts with the catalyst part only through M-O1 bond. As a result, [Sc(CN)(CO2)] gives the shortest M-O1 bond length among the four adducts. It is attributed to the smallest Sc atomic radius among four metals as well as the strongest bonding strength (bond order of 0.81 and FSR of 0.918). As shown in Fig. 4, the most negative CO2 adsorption Gibbs free energy of [Y(CN)], suggests it is more favorable for both activating CO2 and promoting CO formation. This contrasts to [Sc(CN)], which has also a large degree of CO2 activation in the first step, but would be limited to only one catalytic site (the metal center). Along CO2RR, changes of M-O1 and MC2 bonds (M = Sc, Y, La and Ac) were visualized in Figs 5 and S5-S7. Initially the M-O1 bond length decreases, then increases until it is broken, eventually leading to the formation of the new bond MC2. In contrast, the bond order exhibits the converse trend. We will further dig the underlying reasons of CO2 activation by catalysts from their interfacial interactions. In [Y(CN)(CO2)], one would realize three BCPs, Y-O1, C2···N4 and O1···C5, from QTAIM topological analyses (Table 4 ). Although the latter two show relatively long distances (2.011 and 2.680 Å), they lie between the van der Waals radius sum (3.22 and 3.12 Å) and the single covalent bond (1.46 and 1.38 Å). Regarding the C2···N4 BCP, its ρ(r) and ∇²ρ(r) are greater than 0, while H(r) is <0. So it does not belong to either the typical covalent or ionic interactions. The weak interaction can also be ruled out because of its large Eint (−0.834 eV). Mulliken charges (Table S2) show that C2 is a positively charged center. It carries +0.435 electronic charge and acts as an electrophilic site. And N4 is negatively charged, bearing −0.378. Associated with electronic structures in Fig. 6 and Table 5 , the C2···N4 interaction is attributed to a tetrel bond [64,65]. Similarly, the O1···C5 interaction is also a tetrel bond from analyses of distances, QTAIM data, charges and orbitals. And the Y-O1 one is primarily of a dative bond. All these interactions together contribute to the stability of the Yttrium adduct and the activation of CO2. The interfacial interaction between catalyst and CO2 is different in other three adducts. Firstly, all the three adducts have no O1···C5 BCP, although possess the M-O1 BCP. Secondly, the C2···N4 BCP was recognized in [M(CN)(CO2)] (M = La and Ac). Certainly, the same bond type is assigned, i.e., C2···N4 being a tetrel bond and M-O1 a dative bond. The interfacial strength between fragments of catalyst and CO2 can be indicated by values of Eint(tot), provided in Table 4. Its absolute value follows Y > Sc > La > Ac for the adducts [M(CN)(CO2)]. Therefore, the two non-covalent tetrel bonds in addition to the dative one would promote more CO2 activation by the Yttrium catalyst. 3.4 Reaction mechanism To explore the reaction mechanism of the CO2RR process and the catalytic activity of the catalysts, an in-depth analysis of the charge and spin density of the relevant intermediates was performed in Fig. 7 . The adduct [Y(CN)(CO2)] exhibits significant charge transfer (ΔQM = 0.279 and ΔQCO2 = −0.240). It is indicated that during CO2 adsorption, electrons are transferred from the catalyst to the CO2 molecule. It would aid in the CO2 activation and subsequent reduction reactions. So is for other three adducts. Additionally, the electron transfer was visualized from the catalyst moiety to the CO2 part in Fig. 7c. To further elucidate the multi-center synergistic mechanism, we performed NBO analysis [66] (Fig. S10), which indicates that the non-metal center not only stabilizes CO2 through non-covalent tetrel bonding but also participates in orbital interactions that complement charge transfer from the metal center. From the orbital compositions and diagrams of [Y(CN)(CO2)] shown in Table 5 and Fig. 6, bonding orbital interaction between C2 and N4 were observed in H-1. Additionally, an interaction between O1 and C5 was realized in H-21, with respective compositions of 36.81 % and 0.54 %. Associated with geometric, bonding and charge results, C2···N4 and O1···C5 are indeed tetrel bonds. For the CO2 adducts of La and Ac, weak O1···C5 interactions are found in H-31 (Fig. S8) and H-30 (Fig. S9), respectively, which are absent from QTAIM bonding analyses as discussed above. There are some contributions of O1/C5 to these orbitals, corresponding to 11.05 %/2.02 % and 10.55 %/2.02 %. Again, this proves that the O1···C5 interaction in [Y(CN)(CO2)] is comparatively stronger, reinforcing the ability of [Y(CN)] to effectively activate CO2. A detailed analysis of the electronic structural properties can be found in Supporting Information. Therefore, not only the metal but C5 and N4 from the ligand in [Y(CN)] contribute to its catalytic performance. The YCN catalyst offers a noncovalent bond-aided three-center cooperative mechanism towards CO2 activation. This contrasts to the pseudo three centers for La/Ac complexes and single center for Sc complex. Compared to transition metal-supported borophene catalysts [36,37], which primarily activated CO2 through direct metalCO2 interactions, our designed MCN catalysts exhibit a distinct activation mechanism. In addition to metalCO2 dative bonding observed for ScCN, additional non-covalent tetrel-bonding is identified in MCN (M = Y, La and Ac) complexes. These interactions stabilize CO2 adsorption and advance its electron exchange with catalyst. This simultaneously maintains moderate desorption energies. Taken together, an alternative pathway is provided for the efficient CO2RR catalysis. 4 Conclusions Catalytic activation bends the linear structure of CO2, giving 132º∼144º O–C–O angles in the resulted adducts [M(CN)(CO2)] (M = Sc, Y, La and Ac). The CO2→M dative bond is realized in the Sc adduct. Interestingly, two additional noncovalent tetrel bonds are identified in the adducts of Y, La and Ac; and three catalytic active centers (MCN) are provided, which build a planar five-membered ring with CO of adsorbed CO2. Their interfacial strength decreases along Y, Sc, La and Ac, corresponding to Eint(tot) values of −1.999, −1.911, −1.618 and −1.468 eV, respectively. DFT calculations and MD simulations confirm the structural and thermal stability of the MCN catalyst. Among all four, the YCN one showcases superior overall catalytic activity, by requiring the smallest free energy of −0.234 eV for CO2 addition. Large downhill energies indicate the strong stability of forming intermediates *CO2H and *(CO)(H2O). Relatively moderate reaction energies are given during H2O and CO desorption, which are consistent with the Sabatier principle. The CO2RR has been attributed to a three-center cooperative catalysis mechanism, which includes one metal center and two adjacent ligand atoms. In contrast to β12-borophene-supported SACs in previous report, which relied primarily on a single transition metal center, our MCN catalysts introduce multi-center catalytic synergy, enhancing CO2 activation via both metal and non-metal interactions. The presence of non-covalent tetrel bonds further stabilizes CO2 adsorption and promotes electron exchange between catalyst and adsorbate, leading to balanced adsorption/desorption energetics. These findings provide new insights into catalyst design strategies beyond the single-metal SACs, paving the way for more efficient and selective CO2RR electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: With raising carbon neutrality needs, it is crucial to develop efficient catalytic materials that effectively convert atmospheric CO2 to value-added chemicals. The well-studied MNx C single-atom catalysts usually experienced a single-center CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). In the work, the MCN catalysts have been designed by doping Sc/Y/La/Ac into graphitic carbon nitride, in anticipation of fabricating multi-center synergistic catalysis from not only the metal center but adjacent non-metal ligand atoms as well. The CO2RR has been systematically explored using relativistic density functional theory calculations in combination with molecular dynamics simulations. All these catalysts activated CO2 by bending its rigid linear structure. The CO2→M dative bond appears only in the adduct of Sc. Unexpectedly, additional two non-covalent tetrel bonds were recognized in the CO2 adducts of Y, La and Ac. Three catalytic active sites (MCN) are rendered by catalysts, which form a planar five-membered ring with CO of CO2. From a thermodynamic perspective, the YCN complex suggests the best catalytic potential. It has the most negative (-0.247 eV) and moderate (0.662 eV) free energy changes for CO2 adsorption and CO desorption, respectively. Further analyses on geometric/electronic structures and chemical bonding confirm the excellent stability and electronic transfer capability of MCN catalyst in activating CO2.
